text.p: Here are the highlights from Swiss newspapers on Friday:

- About 86 percent of the Swiss population are still members of either the Protestant or the Roman-Catholic church, the Federal Bureau for Statistics wrote. Based on the 1990 census, the office said 46.2 percent were Roman-Catholic and 40 percent Protestants. The Protestants, traditionally the largest religous group in Switzerland, have been outnumbered by Catholics since the 1950s as workers from Italy and Spain immigrated to Switzerland.
- Advertisements in Swiss daily newspapers stagnated in July as the number of ads remained on the same level as in June. Job ads registered a slight increase.

- The weekly newspaper SonntagsZeitung fired editor-in-chief Ueli Haldimann after the paper manipulated a quote by right-wing politician Christoph Blocher to make it appear he had said there were no more survivors of the Holocaust alive today.
- One out of three restaurants in Switzerland may have to shut down, according to a study by service sector labour union Unia.
Unia said about 70,000 jobs might be endangered as the restaurant business continues to be pressured by a six years by slow recovery from a long Swiss recesion.

- Best Western chain hotels in Switzerland reported a 20 percent increase in turnover in the 1997 first semester compared to the same period last year. The number of over-night stays at the 78 hotels rose by 20 percent.

- Former Swiss Bank Corp CEO Roland Rasi has been temporarily appointed new boss at troubled Swiss health insurer Visana. - Swiss watch industry registered an 7.8 percent increase to 3,857 million Swiss francs in exports in the 1997 first semester.
